Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences in Mathematics for Undergraduates and Teachers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The REU/RET in mathematics at California State University, Chico targets secondary teachers with a strong interest in mathematics or statistics and undergraduate students who have completed their junior year. For six weeks of each summer, twelve participants, including three teachers, will work in three research teams on problems selected from Knot Theory, Algebra, Mathematical Modeling, Statistics, and Number Theory. Depending on the field, projects may be appropriate for students from scientific disciplines other than mathematics.

The research experience is intended to give participants an appreciation for the breadth and depth of mathematics and its applications, while providing undergraduates an opportunity to improve their communication skills and also providing in-service teachers an experience which will deepen their understanding of mathematical content and inspire pedagogical innovation in their classrooms. By working on open problems in mathematics, participants will experience the excitement of exploration, discovery, analysis, proof, and systematization that are part of the mathematician's world. While much of mathematics is accessible only after years of study, the field is rich enough to allow for a fuller mathematical experience at the undergraduate level. The site is co-funded by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The period of from 05/01/2015 - 04/30/2016 was the no-cost extension of our initially three year project without any additional funding.The left over funds were used for participating and presenting at the research conferences. During this period the faculty-supervisors continue collaboration with their team members (students and teachers) by e-mail. 

Overall, through the last REUT award #1156612 (2012-2015, extended to 2016), we recruited 27 undergraduate students and 9 high school teachers.We have made 30 presentations at national and regional conferences and published 10 research papers in professional peer-reviewed journals.

Peer-reviewed journal publications (undergraduate co-authors and teachers are starred.) :

2. S. Fomin, R. Shankar*, N. Danes*, A. Yasuda*, V. Chugunov, ”Rimming flow of a weakly elastic fluid”, Theoretical and Computational Fluid Mechanics, 28, 2014, pp.485–498. 
3. V. Chugunov , S. Fomin, R. Shankar*, “Mathematical modeling of the tsunami run-up on a sloping beach”, Journal of Geophysical Research - Oceans, 119, 2014, pp. 7568–7591.
4. R. Shankar*, Y. Sheng*, M. Golbek*, T. Hartland*, M. Brandao*, S. Fomin, P. Gerrodette*, “Linear Long Wave Propagation Over Discontinuous Submerged Shallow Water Topography” Applied Mathematics and Computation, 252, 2015, pp.27-44.
5. S. Fomin, R. Shankar*, P. Haine*, “Stability Analysis of Non-Newtonian Rimming Flow”, Applied Mathematical Modeling, 40, 2016, pp. 2999–3010.
6. Gray, Kathy; Hampton, Brittany; Silveti-Falls, Tony; McConnell, Allison; and Bausell, Casey (2015) "Comparison of Bayesian Credible Intervals to Frequentist Confidence Intervals," Journal of Modern Applied Statistical Methods: 14: Iss. 1, Article 8. 
7. Gray, K., Keane, R., Karpisz, R.*, Pedersen, A.*, Russell, T.*, Brown, R*. (2016) Bayesian techniques for surface fuel loading estimation. Accepted for publication as a Research Note RMRS-RN.
8. K. Grimshaw*, A. Kling*, F. Li*, T. Landry*, S. Goberstein, “Characterization of perfect congruences on a large class of bisimple ?-semigroups”, Semigroup Forum, 91 (2015), No. 1, pp. 117-127.
9. Shankar, Ravi. (2015) “Numerical computation of wave breaking times”. SIAM Undergraduate Research Journal 8, 138¬149.
